reviewText: The doc itself is excellent with plenty of game footage and focusing on the two main owners (the New Jersey Generals' Donald Trump and the Tampa Bay Bandits' John Bassett) who were the flip sides of the coin in the USFL's spring vs. fall schedule battle was a brilliant way to approach the subject.Considering, though, that the director ran USFL Films, why does so much of the game footage look like it's just bad video. Given this was the '80s, not the '70s, the pic quality even on video (why was the USFL game footage not shot on film a la NFL Films?) is pathetic. It at times looks like bad YouTube footage.Another weird snippet is interviewing the man (Bill Simmons) behind the 30 for 30 idea about some Boston Breakers game as sort of representative of the excitement of the USFL. Now, I don't know about you, but beyond the fact they had a cool logo and spent their three years in the USFL moving their home across the nation from Boston to New Orleans to Portland and kept the team name the same, I don't see the significance of putting that in. I'd like to have seen more stuff on the teams that actually registered on our consciousness.
summary: poor video quality on hilite shots

reviewText: This is definitely not an in-depth retrospective fo the USFL itself.  It is  quite good at proving Donald Trump pretty much was the worst thing ever for the spring league.  Would love to see more of a true historical sense of the league done some day by the producer, as he obviously has the knowledge and footage to do such a project.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just as the USFL is a footnote today, the documentary of it has been overlooked amid the other "30 for 30" films. That's a shame as this hour long feature is a fun look back at the creation of the United States Football League, an attempt at summer football that began in 1983 after pulling off the shocking signing of college star Herschel Walker. The league did have surprising success thanks to exposure on a young ESPN and some actually good players and games. Michael Tollin helped the USFL create their video packages and thus his direction gives unique insight to the league (if a bit self-serving on it success). He delves less on how it began and more on how it fell apart as owners (especially Donald Trump) made the mistake of reaching too far too soon, wanting to go head-to-head with the NFL before they were ready. The highlight of the doc is Tollin meeting Trump today, the man incredibly rude and arrogant, claiming he was the only one who could make the USFL a success and literally brushing aside Tollin's evidence to the contrary. It's also fascinating to see how some of the USFL's play innovations used by the NFL later. The extras flesh it out more to enjoy a brief but memorable run by a league whose behind-the-scenes battles put the gridiron to shame.
summary: A great look back at a rival football league and how Donald Trump helped kill it
Title: N/A

reviewText: Mike Tollin, a former league employee (whohelped 'make' The Donald, in a footballsense, recaptured in this important film,a very important part of football, and myfirst job out of college. Thank you verylittle, Donald Trump. And I won't be votingfor you for President! Pick Up On It!
summary: Outstanding!! Don't forget this fine film by Mike Tollin (or the USFL)!!

reviewText: As a big fan of the USFL's Jacksonville Bulls I had to see this DVD. It more than lived up to expectations. You need to add this to your collection because someday this will be a collector's item. Did Donald Trump kill the USFL? Judge for yourself. How could a league boasting quarterbacks like Steve Young, Brian Sipe, Jim Kelley,Doug Williams, Bobby Hebert,Jefferson Street Joe Gillam the black Joe Namath, Matt Robinson,& Doug Flutie with Herschel Walker in his backfield fail. Even Reggie White played.
Title: N/A
